Warm Up (5 minutes)


This warm-up reviews and reinforces the idea that exponents can be represented equivalently as repeated multiplication. Students will translate constant and variable bases with exponents to multiplication expressions.

Launch

Display the introduction and the example expressions. Ask the class to explain the relationship between exponents and repeated multiplication. Display the exponential expressions. Give students quiet think-time for each problem and ask them to give a signal when they have an answer. Keep all problems displayed throughout the talk. Follow with a whole-class discussion as needed to review the answers.


Student Activity

An exponent indicates repeated multiplication of the same quantity.

Expand each exponential expression to show repeated multiplication.

  1. \(4^3\) = ____________

    2. Answer: \(4 \cdot 4 \cdot 4\)

  2. \(x^5\) = ____________

    3. Answer: \(x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x \cdot x\)

  3. \( (-8)^6\) = ____________

    4. Answer: \((-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8) \cdot (-8)\)

  4. \((-z)^3\) = ____________

    5. Answer: \((-z) \cdot (-z) \cdot (-z)\)

Activity Synthesis

Invite students to share their answers as each expression is simplified into repeated multiplication. Then, discuss with students:

  • “What is the relationship between the base of the exponent and the factor used in the repeated multiplication expression?” (The base of the exponent is the same value or variable that is used in the repeated multiplication expression.)
  • “What is the relationship between the exponent value and the number of factors in the repeated multiplication expression?” (The exponent value will be equal to the number of factors in the repeated multiplication expression.)
